items.question: How long does an infrastructure penetration test take?
items.answer: Typically 1-3 weeks depending on the scope and complexity of your infrastructure.

items.question: Do we need to give you VPN access?
items.answer: For internal testing, VPN access is required. For external testing, only public-facing assets are tested.

items.question: Will testing disrupt our operations?
items.answer: We use non-disruptive testing methods during business hours and coordinate any intrusive tests.

items.question: What happens if you find critical vulnerabilities?
items.answer: We immediately notify your security team and provide remediation guidance.

items.question: Do you test our cloud infrastructure as well?
items.answer: Yes, we test both on-premise and cloud infrastructure including AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud.

items.question: What credentials do you need from us?
items.answer: Credentials vary by test type - from no credentials for black-box testing to domain admin for comprehensive testing.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.content: At sodusecure, we are committed to protecting your privacy. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, disclose, and safeguard your information when you visit our website.

collect.title: Information We Collect
collect.intro: We may collect information about you in a variety of ways. The information we may collect on the site includes:

personalItems.name: Name, email address, phone number, and contact information

usageItems.pages: Pages visited and time spent on pages

use.title: How We Use Your Information
use.intro: We use the information we collect in the following ways:

items.provide: To provide, operate, and maintain our services
items.process: To process transactions and send related information
items.admin: To manage your account and provide customer support
items.respond: To respond to your inquiries and fulfill your requests
items.monitor: To monitor and analyze usage patterns and trends
items.detect: To detect, prevent, and address technical issues and security threats
items.marketing: To send you marketing and promotional communications (with your consent)
items.comply: To comply with legal obligations and enforce our terms

sharing.title: Sharing Your Information
sharing.intro: We may share your information in the following situations:
sharing.providersDesc: We share information with third-party service providers who perform services on our behalf
sharing.transfersDesc: We may share or transfer your information in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale of assets
sharing.legalDesc: We may disclose your information if required by law or in response to valid requests by public authorities
sharing.consentDesc: We may share your information for any other purpose with your consent
sharing.notSell: We do not sell, trade, or rent your personal information to third parties for marketing purposes.

security.title: Security of Your Information
security.content: We use administrative, technical, and physical security measures to protect your personal information. However, no method of transmission over the internet or electronic storage is 100% secure, and we cannot guarantee absolute security.

rights.title: Your Privacy Rights
rights.intro: Depending on your location, you may have the following rights regarding your personal information:
rights.accessDesc: Request access to your personal information
rights.correctionDesc: Request correction of inaccurate or incomplete information
rights.deletionDesc: Request deletion of your personal information
rights.portabilityDesc: Request a copy of your information in a portable format
rights.optOutDesc: Opt out of marketing communications and data processing
rights.withdrawDesc: Withdraw your consent for data processing at any time
rights.contact: To exercise any of these rights, please contact us using the information provided below.

cookies.title: Cookies and Tracking Technologies
cookies.intro: We use cookies and similar tracking technologies to track activity on our service and store certain information. Types of cookies we use:
cookies.essentialDesc: Required for the website to function properly
cookies.performanceDesc: Help us understand how visitors interact with our website
cookies.marketingDesc: Used to deliver relevant advertisements to you
cookies.browser: You can instruct your browser to refuse all cookies or to indicate when a cookie is being sent. However, if you do not accept cookies, you may not be able to use some portions of our service.

retention.title: Data Retention
retention.content: We retain your personal information only for as long as necessary to fulfill the purposes for which we collected it, including for the purposes of satisfying any legal, accounting, or reporting requirements. When we no longer need your information, we will securely delete or anonymize it.

children.title: Children's Privacy
children.content: Our service is not intended for children under the age of 13. We do not knowingly collect personal information from children under 13. If you are a parent or guardian and you are aware that your child has provided us with personal information, please contact us.

international.title: International Data Transfers
international.content: Your information may be transferred to and maintained on computers located outside of your state, province, country, or other governmental jurisdiction where data protection laws may differ. By using our service, you consent to the transfer of your information to our facilities and those third parties with whom we share it.

changes.title: Changes to This Privacy Policy
changes.intro: We may update our Privacy Policy from time to time. We will notify you of any changes by posting the new Privacy Policy on this page and updating the "Last updated" date.
changes.effective: You are advised to review this Privacy Policy periodically for any changes. Changes to this Privacy Policy are effective when they are posted on this page.

contact.title: Contact Us
contact.intro: If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy, please contact us:

introduction.title: Agreement to Terms
introduction.content: These Terms of Service and any related documents constitute the entire agreement and supersede all prior negotiations, representations or agreements, both written and oral.

acceptance.title: Acceptance of Terms
acceptance.content: By accessing and using this website, you accept and agree to be bound by the terms and provision of this agreement. If you do not agree to abide by these terms, please do not use this service.

license.title: Use License
license.intro: Permission is granted to temporarily download one copy of the materials on sodusecure's website for personal, non-commercial transitory viewing only. This is the grant of a license, not a transfer of title, and under this license you may not:

items.modify: Use the materials for any commercial purpose or for any public display
items.commercial: Attempt to reverse engineer any software contained on sodusecure's website
items.reverse: Remove any copyright or other proprietary notations from the materials

account.title: User Accounts
account.content: When you create an account with us, you must provide accurate, complete, and current information. Failure to do so constitutes a breach of the Terms, which may result in immediate termination of your account.

privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.content: Your use of our service is also governed by our Privacy Policy. Please review our Privacy Policy, which also governs the Site and informs users of our data collection practices.

prohibited.title: Prohibited Uses
prohibited.intro: You may use the Service only for lawful purposes and in accordance with Terms. You agree not to use the Service:

items.violating: In any way that violates any applicable national or international law or regulation
items.framing: To transmit, or procure the sending of, any advertising or promotional material without our prior written consent
items.uploading: To impersonate or attempt to impersonate the Company, a Company employee, another user, or any other person or entity
items.impersonate: In any way that infringes upon the rights of others, or in any way is illegal, threatening, fraudulent, or harmful
items.harassing: To engage in any other conduct that restricts or inhibits anyone's use or enjoyment of Service

intellectual.title: Intellectual Property
intellectual.content: The Service and its original content, features, and functionality are and will remain the exclusive property of sodusecure and its licensors. The Service is protected by copyright, trademark, and other laws.

limitation.title: Limitation of Liability
limitation.content: In no event shall sodusecure, nor its directors, employees, partners, agents, suppliers, or affiliates, be liable for any indirect, incidental, special, consequential or punitive damages, including without limitation, loss of profits, data, use, goodwill, or other intangible losses.

termination.title: Termination
termination.content: We may terminate or suspend your account and bar access to Service immediately, without prior notice or liability, under our sole discretion, for any reason whatsoever and without limitation, including but not limited to a breach of Terms.

changes.title: Changes to Terms
changes.content: We reserve the right, at our sole discretion, to modify or replace these Terms at any time. If a revision is material, we will provide at least 30 days notice prior to any new terms taking effect.

contact.title: Contact Us
contact.intro: If you have any questions about these Terms of Service, please contact us:

blogDetail.title: OWASP Top 10 2024: What Changed and Why It Matters
blogDetail.description: A comprehensive guide to the latest OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities and actionable security strategies for modern applications.
blogDetail.author: Sodu Secure Team

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.content: In the ever-evolving landscape of cybersecurity, staying ahead of emerging threats is crucial for organizations of all sizes. This comprehensive guide explores the latest developments in vulnerabilities and provides actionable strategies for security teams.

keyTakeaway.title: Key Takeaway
keyTakeaway.content: Modern applications face numerous security challenges. Understanding these vulnerabilities is the first step toward building resilient systems. In this article, we examine the most critical security issues affecting today's applications.

introduction.quote: Security is not a product, but a process. It's not just about tools, it's about people, processes, and technology working together to create a resilient security posture.

commonAttackVectors.title: Common Attack Vectors
items: SQL injection and database manipulation attacks
Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities in web applications
Insecure API endpoints and authentication management flaws
Insecure direct object references exposing sensitive data
Broken access control and authorization flaws

impactAnalysis.title: Impact Analysis
impactAnalysis.content: The consequences of security vulnerabilities can be severe, ranging from data breaches to complete system compromise. Understanding these risks helps organizations prioritize their security efforts effectively and allocate resources appropriately.

averageCost.label: Average cost of a data breach

identificationTime.label: Avg time to identify and contain

mitigationStrategies.title: Mitigation Strategies
mitigationStrategies.content: Implementing effective security controls requires a multi-layered approach. Here are proven strategies to strengthen your organization's security posture against common threats.

essentialPractices.title: Essential Security Practices
items: Implement defense in depth with multiple security layers
Conduct regular security assessments and penetration testing
Maintain up-to-date security policies and patches
Enforce strong authentication and access controls
Perform regular code reviews and security audits
Implement proper input validation and output encoding

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.content1: Security is an ongoing journey, not a destination. By staying informed about emerging threats and implementing robust security practices, organizations can significantly reduce their risk exposure. Regular assessments, continuous monitoring, and a security-first culture are essential components of any comprehensive security strategy.
conclusion.content2: If you need professional security assessment services, our team of certified experts is here to help. Contact us today to discuss how we can strengthen your security posture and protect your digital assets.

cta.title: Need Professional Security Testing?
cta.description: Get expert penetration testing and security assessment services tailored to your organization's needs.

articles.title: API Security Best Practices for 2024
articles.description: Essential strategies to secure your APIs against modern threats and vulnerabilities.

articles.title: Zero-Day Vulnerabilities: Detection and Response
articles.description: How to detect, respond to, and mitigate zero-day vulnerabilities in your organization.

authorBio.name: Sodu Secure Team
authorBio.bio: Our team of certified security experts has years of experience in penetration testing and security research.

react4shellDetail.title: React 4 Shell: RCE Vulnerability and Remediation Strategies
react4shellDetail.description: A comprehensive security analysis of CVE-2024-50980 – understand the risks, detect threats in your environment, and implement secure update paths.
react4shellDetail.author: Sodu Secure Team

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.content: React 4 Shell is a widely-used frontend library used by thousands of developers worldwide. The recently discovered vulnerability CVE-2024-50980 enables Remote Code Execution (RCE) through manipulated inputs. In this article, we show you what this vulnerability means, how to identify it in your infrastructure, and how to fix it securely.

keyTakeaway.title: Key Takeaway
keyTakeaway.content: CVE-2024-50980 is a critical Remote Code Execution vulnerability in React 4 Shell < 1.8.4. Organizations using this version should upgrade immediately to the patched version. This article shows you a safe migration path for production environments.

introduction.quote: Remote Code Execution is one of the most critical security flaws that exist. A component used in most modern React applications makes this flaw a priority for every developer.

commonAttackVectors.title: Technical Details of the Vulnerability
items: Insecure template rendering logic in React 4 Shell versions < 1.8.4
Missing input validation when processing dynamic components
Insufficient output escaping in JSX generation
Exploitation through specially crafted URL parameters or POST data
Enables arbitrary JavaScript code execution in server context
Potential database access and privilege escalation

impactAnalysis.title: Impact Analysis
impactAnalysis.content: The impact of CVE-2024-50980 is far-reaching. An attacker could execute arbitrary code on the server, read files, compromise databases, or inject malware. This is particularly critical for production environments processing sensitive customer data.

mitigationStrategies.title: Remediation and Update Strategies
mitigationStrategies.content: Fixing this vulnerability requires a structured approach. Immediate actions should be combined with long-term strategies. Here we show a proven update path for different scenarios.

essentialPractices.title: Step-by-Step Remediation Plan
items: Step 1: Inventory all React 4 Shell installations in your infrastructure
Step 2: Update to React 4 Shell >= 1.8.4 in a test environment
Step 3: Conduct comprehensive regression testing (UI, API, data flow)
Step 4: Plan staged rollout to staging environment
Step 5: Monitor for anomalies during rollout
Step 6: Enable enhanced logging and WAF rules during update
Step 8: Document the process and test results for compliance

conclusion.title: Conclusion and Next Steps
conclusion.content1: CVE-2024-50980 is a serious security risk that requires immediate attention. Through a structured update procedure, you can minimize risk and ensure the stability of your applications.
conclusion.content2: Sodu Secure provides professional penetration testing and security assessments to identify such critical vulnerabilities in your infrastructure before attackers discover them. Contact us for a comprehensive Web Application Pentest or security audit of your React-based applications.

cta.title: Is Your React Application Secure?
cta.description: Have your applications thoroughly tested by certified security experts. We identify critical vulnerabilities before they are exploited.

articles.title: OWASP Top 10 2024: What's Changed
articles.description: A deep dive into the latest OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities.

articles.title: API Security Best Practices for 2024
articles.description: Key strategies to protect your APIs.

authorBio.name: Sodu Secure Team
authorBio.bio: Our team of certified security experts has extensive experience in Web Application Security and vulnerability analysis.

openClawDetail.title: OpenClaw Security Risks: Understanding AI Chatbot Vulnerabilities
openClawDetail.description: A detailed analysis of security risks from integrating OpenClaw and other AI chatbots – prompt injection, data exfiltration, and practical mitigation strategies.
openClawDetail.author: Sodu Secure Team

introduction.title: Introduction to AI Security
introduction.content: OpenClaw and other Large Language Models (LLMs) offer revolutionary capabilities but also introduce new security risks. In this article, we explore the main threats associated with integrating AI chatbots and show you how to mitigate them.

keyTakeaway.title: Critical Insight
keyTakeaway.content: AI chatbots can be attacked through prompt injection – a new class of attacks targeting LLMs specifically. These attacks can expose sensitive data, execute unintended commands, or turn the chatbot against your users.

introduction.quote: With growing integration of AI in business-critical processes, enterprises must understand a new security paradigm. AI security is not just technical – it's about trust, transparency, and control.

commonAttackVectors.title: Common AI Security Risks
items: Prompt Injection Attacks – malicious inputs that make LLMs perform unintended actions
Data Exfiltration – attackers attempt to make models reveal sensitive training data
Jailbreaking – techniques to bypass safety guidelines and guardrails
Model Poisoning – attackers train models with malicious data
Denial of Service (DoS) – overwhelming AI systems with resource-intensive queries
Unauthorized API Access – insufficient authentication and rate limiting

impactAnalysis.title: Business Impact
impactAnalysis.content: An AI security incident can have far-reaching consequences – from reputation damage to data loss to operational disruption. As dependency on AI systems grows, they must be protected as rigorously as traditional infrastructure.

identificationTime.label: Average cost of AI security incident

mitigationStrategies.title: Security Strategies for AI Integration
mitigationStrategies.content: There are proven techniques to make AI chatbots more secure. A defense-in-depth strategy with multiple security layers is required.

essentialPractices.title: Security Measures for AI Bots
items: Implement input validation and output filtering on all API endpoints
Use Content Security Policies (CSP) to limit prompt injection
Implement granular access control and API key management
Monitor queries for suspicious patterns and unusual usage
Set limits on token usage and query complexity
Implement logging and audit trails for all interactions
Conduct regular red-team testing against your AI systems
Train your team in AI security best practices and common attack patterns

conclusion.title: AI Security as Strategic Priority
conclusion.content1: AI security is not optional – it's a business requirement. Organizations implementing AI responsibly will gain a competitive advantage.
conclusion.content2: Sodu Secure offers specialized penetration testing for AI systems and LLM integrations. We identify prompt injection vulnerabilities, API weaknesses, and data privacy risks before attackers exploit them. Contact us for a comprehensive AI Security Assessment.

cta.title: Is Your AI Integration Secure?
cta.description: Have your OpenClaw integration and AI systems tested by experts. We uncover hidden security risks.

articles.title: API Security Best Practices for 2024
articles.description: Key strategies to protect your APIs.

articles.title: Cloud Security Checklist: AWS, Azure, GCP

authorBio.bio: Our team specializes in AI system security and Large Language Models with comprehensive experience in identifying AI vulnerabilities.

smePentestDetail.title: Cybersecurity for SMEs: When You Really Need a Pentest
smePentestDetail.description: A practical guide for small and medium enterprises – when penetration testing is necessary, what types exist, and how they help your business.
smePentestDetail.author: Sodu Secure Team

introduction.title: Why SMEs Must Take Security Seriously
introduction.content: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are frequent targets of cyberattacks. They often have fewer security resources than large corporations but just as much to lose. This guide shows you how penetration testing can help your SME and when the right time is.

keyTakeaway.title: Core Message
keyTakeaway.content: SMEs are preferred targets for hackers – weaker defenses but valuable data. A single successful attack can be existential for an SME. A pentest is not a luxury – it's a necessary business risk management tool.

introduction.quote: For SMEs, security is not 'nice to have' – it's business continuity. A data breach can not only destroy your reputation but also have legal consequences. You need to know and understand these risks.

commonAttackVectors.title: Most Common Attack Vectors Against SMEs
items: Phishing attacks and social engineering against employees
Weak passwords and lack of multi-factor authentication
Outdated software and missing security patches
Unsecured remote access systems and VPNs
Weak configurations in cloud systems (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud)
Missing or unencrypted backups and data management

impactAnalysis.title: Financial and Business Impact
impactAnalysis.content: A cyberattack on an SME often has catastrophic impacts. Not just direct financial losses, but also operational disruption, reputation damage, and potentially bankruptcy.

averageCost.label: Average cost of cyberattack for SME

identificationTime.label: Average time to detection of attack

mitigationStrategies.title: When and How to Conduct a Pentest
mitigationStrategies.content: Penetration testing is an important security measure, but it's crucial to understand when it delivers the most value and what types are suitable for your SME.

essentialPractices.title: Pentest Strategy for SMEs
items: Timing 1: Before your first major customer project or when security becomes critical
Timing 2: After major system changes, upgrades, or cloud migration
Timing 3: At least annually if you process customer data
Timing 4: After suspicious security events or malware infections
Choose Test Type: External Pentest for website/API (€5,000-15,000), Internal for network (€8,000-20,000)
Budget Tip: Start with Web Application Pentest as this often carries the highest risk
Frequency: After initial pentest, conduct annual security assessments
Measurability: Track how many findings are remediated and measure security progress

conclusion.title: Investment in Security = Investment in Business Continuity
conclusion.content1: For SMEs, a pentest is not optional – it's a necessary business management tool. A good understanding of your organization's security posture helps you make informed decisions and minimize risks.
conclusion.content2: Sodu Secure specializes in cost-effective yet thorough penetration testing for SMEs. We understand the specific requirements and budgets of smaller businesses and offer tailored solutions. From simple Web Application Security Assessment to comprehensive Network Penetration Testing – contact us for a free consultation.

cta.title: Ready to Protect Your SME?
cta.description: Start with a free security assessment. Our experts identify the biggest risks for your business.
cta.buttonText: Request Free Security Consultation for SMEs

owaspTop10_2026Detail.title: OWASP Top 10 2026: New Risks, New Priorities
owaspTop10_2026Detail.description: A practical outlook on OWASP Top 10 2026 – emerging trends and what to prioritize now.
owaspTop10_2026Detail.author: Sodu Secure Team

introduction.title: Setting the Context for 2026
introduction.content: The OWASP Top 10 is not a static checklist—it reflects the current web risk landscape. For 2026, clear trends are emerging: more complexity from microservices, more AI-driven abuse, and increasing dependence on third-party components.

keyTakeaway.title: Key Takeaway
keyTakeaway.content: To be resilient in 2026, organizations must combine security fundamentals (access control, input validation, logging) with modern safeguards (supply-chain security, API protection, secrets management).

introduction.quote: OWASP Top 10 doesn't mean ten items to tick off—it means ten priorities to manage continuously.

commonAttackVectors.title: Risk Trends Likely to Dominate in 2026
items: Broken access control in distributed architectures
Insecure API endpoints and insufficient authentication
Insecure design and lack of threat modeling
Misconfigurations in cloud and container environments
Weak secrets and key management in CI/CD pipelines

impactAnalysis.title: Why These Risks Are Business-Critical
impactAnalysis.content: The damage ranges from data loss and downtime to regulatory penalties. The combination of automation and complexity means mistakes propagate faster and wider than ever.

mitigationStrategies.title: Practical Actions for 2026
mitigationStrategies.content: Security starts at design time. For 2026, prioritize standards and testing that reflect modern attack paths.

essentialPractices.title: Prioritized Security Checks
items: Run regular web and API penetration tests
Establish mandatory threat modeling per feature
Harden CI/CD with secrets scanning and signing
Train teams in secure development practices

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.content1: OWASP Top 10 2026 will be shaped by complexity, automation, and supply-chain risk. Organizations that invest now will reduce exposure long term.
conclusion.content2: Sodu Secure supports you with web and API pentests, threat modeling, and security reviews. Talk to us to align your 2026 security strategy.

cta.title: Ready for OWASP Top 10 2026?
cta.description: Review your web and API landscape and prioritize the right risks now.

articles.title: OWASP Top 10 2024: What's Changed
articles.description: A deep dive into the latest OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities.

articles.title: API Security Best Practices for 2024
articles.description: Key strategies to protect your APIs.

authorBio.bio: Our team helps organizations prioritize web risks and build sustainable secure development processes.

caseStudyDetail.title: Securing a FinTech Web Application
caseStudyDetail.description: Comprehensive security assessment uncovered critical vulnerabilities in payment processing flows, preventing potential financial losses and ensuring regulatory compliance.

clientOverview.title: Client Overview
clientOverview.content: Our client is a leading finance company serving over 2 million users globally. As they prepared to scale their platform, they needed comprehensive security testing to ensure their infrastructure could withstand modern cyber threats while maintaining regulatory compliance and customer trust.

challenge.title: The Challenge
challenge.intro: The organization faced several critical security concerns:
items: Legacy systems integrated with modern cloud infrastructure created complex attack surfaces
Rapid development cycles meant security testing was often deprioritized
Compliance requirements demanded thorough documentation and remediation
Previous automated scans had missed critical business logic vulnerabilities
Payment processing systems handling millions in daily transactions

phases.description: We began with thorough reconnaissance, mapping all assets, technologies, and potential entry points. This included OSINT gathering, subdomain enumeration, and technology fingerprinting.
Manual testing combined with automated tools to identify vulnerabilities across all layers of the application stack, from infrastructure to business logic.
Safe exploitation of discovered vulnerabilities to validate impact and demonstrate real-world attack scenarios to stakeholders.
Detailed reports with executive summaries, technical findings, and remediation guidance. Ongoing support during the fix process.

keyFindings.title: Key Findings
keyFindings.summary: Our comprehensive assessment revealed 47 vulnerabilities across multiple severity levels, with particular focus on payment processing security.

critical.title: Critical Vulnerabilities
items: SQL injection in payment processing API allowing unauthorized database access
Broken authentication mechanism enabling account takeover
Insecure direct object references exposing sensitive financial data

high.title: High Severity
items: Insecure file upload allowing remote code execution
Weak encryption of stored payment card data
Missing rate limiting on authentication endpoints

impactAnalysis.title: Impact Analysis
impactAnalysis.content: The discovered vulnerabilities could have led to significant financial losses, regulatory non-compliance, and damage to customer trust. Our assessment prevented potential breaches that could have cost millions in remediation and lost business.

remediation.title: Remediation & Results
remediation.content: Working closely with the development team, we implemented comprehensive fixes for all critical and high-severity vulnerabilities within the agreed timeframe.

timeline.title: Remediation Timeline
timeline.low: Low-priority items addressed during regular maintenance

outcomes.title: Key Outcomes
items: All critical vulnerabilities eliminated before production deployment
Development team trained on secure coding practices
Automated security testing integrated into CI/CD pipeline

cta.title: Ready to Secure Your Application?
cta.description: Don't wait for a breach to happen. Get professional security testing today.

testimonials.title: What Our Clients Say
testimonials.quote: "Sodu Secure's thorough assessment gave us the confidence to scale our platform. Their expertise in financial services security was invaluable."
testimonials.author: CTO, FinTech Company

oscpPathDetail.title: Beyond OSCP: Which Offensive Security Certification is Right for You?
oscpPathDetail.description: After OSCP, the journey continues – OSEP, OSWE, OSED and more. A detailed guide to advanced Offensive Security certifications and how to level up your penetration testing career.
oscpPathDetail.author: Sodu Secure Team

introduction.title: The OSCP Journey Doesn't End – It Just Begins
introduction.content: Congratulations – you've passed the OSCP (Offensive Security Certified Professional)! This legendary certification has taught you how to attack real systems and shaped your mindset as a pentester. But many wonder: what comes next? The good news: Offensive Security offers several advanced certifications covering different specializations.

keyTakeaway.title: Key Takeaway
keyTakeaway.content: Choosing the right post-OSCP certification depends on your career goals, interests, and technical strengths. Each certification opens different doors – from Advanced Penetration Testing to Web Application Security to Exploit Development.

introduction.quote: After OSCP success, it's not about collecting more certificates – it's about diving deep into areas that truly excite you and provide the greatest value for your career.

osepOverview.title: OSEP: Offensive Security Experienced Penetration Tester
osepOverview.subtitle: For advanced Red Team Operations and Evasion Techniques
osepOverview.content: OSEP (formerly known as PEN-300) is the direct continuation of OSCP and targets pentesters who want to deepen their skills in realistic enterprise environments. Here you learn how to deal with modern detection and prevention mechanisms.

topics.title: What you'll learn in OSEP:
items: Active Directory Attacks (Kerberos, NTLM, Golden Tickets)
C# and PowerShell for Offensive Tooling

examInfo.title: Exam Details:
examInfo.goal: Compromise a simulated enterprise environment with multiple network segments
examInfo.difficulty: Significantly harder than OSCP – requires deep understanding of Windows internals

osepOverview.bestFor: Ideal for: Red Teamers, Advanced Pentesters, Security Consultants who want to simulate enterprise attacks

osweOverview.title: OSWE: Offensive Security Web Expert
osweOverview.subtitle: For White-Box Web Application Security Specialists
osweOverview.content: OSWE (WEB-300) is perfect for those who want to specialize in Web Application Security. Unlike OSCP, the focus here is on white-box testing and source code review.

topics.title: What you'll learn in OSWE:
items: Manual code review of web applications (PHP, Java, .NET, Node.js)
Custom Exploit Development for web apps

examInfo.title: Exam Details:
examInfo.goal: Identify and exploit vulnerabilities in two web applications based on source code
examInfo.difficulty: Requires very good programming skills and understanding of web frameworks

osweOverview.bestFor: Ideal for: Web App Penetration Testers, Bug Bounty Hunters, Application Security Engineers conducting in-depth code analysis

osedOverview.title: OSED: Offensive Security Exploit Developer
osedOverview.subtitle: For Binary Exploitation and Exploit Development Experts
osedOverview.content: OSED (EXP-301) is the most challenging of the post-OSCP certifications and focuses on Windows Exploit Development – a field requiring deep technical understanding.

topics.title: What you'll learn in OSED:
items: x86 Assembly and Debugging (WinDbg, Immunity Debugger)
Stack Buffer Overflows (SEH, DEP, ASLR Bypasses)
Exploit Development against modern Windows protections

examInfo.title: Exam Details:
examInfo.goal: Develop working exploits for multiple Windows binaries
examInfo.difficulty: Extremely challenging – requires deep understanding of processor architecture and memory management

osedOverview.bestFor: Ideal for: Exploit Developers, Vulnerability Researchers, Malware Analysts entering binary exploitation

otherCerts.title: Other Offensive Security Certifications
otherCerts.content: Besides OSEP, OSWE, and OSED, there are other specialized Offensive Security certifications:

certifications.name: OSWP (Offensive Security Wireless Professional)
certifications.description: Focus on Wireless Network Penetration Testing – WLAN security, Encryption Attacks, Rogue Access Points

certifications.name: OSDA (Offensive Security Defense Analyst)
certifications.description: The defensive perspective – SOC Analysis, Threat Hunting, SIEM, Incident Response

certifications.name: OSMR (Offensive Security macOS Researcher)
certifications.description: Specialization in macOS Security – macOS Internals, Privilege Escalation, Objective-C Exploitation

certifications.name: OSEE (Offensive Security Exploitation Expert)
certifications.description: The ultimate challenge – advanced exploitation techniques, Kernel Exploitation, Zero-Day Research

decisionGuide.title: Decision Guide: Which Certification Fits You?
decisionGuide.content: The choice depends on several factors:

scenarios.profile: You want to conduct Red Team operations
scenarios.recommendation: OSEP is the best choice. You'll learn realistic attack techniques against enterprise environments.

scenarios.profile: You love web applications and programming
scenarios.recommendation: OSWE is perfect. You'll become a Web Application Security expert with white-box focus.
OSED opens the door to the world of binary exploitation and exploit development.

scenarios.profile: You want to build broad knowledge
scenarios.recommendation: Start with OSEP (more generalist), then specialize with OSWE or OSED.
OSWE helps you find complex web vulnerabilities that others overlook.

preparation.title: Preparation and Tips
preparation.content: Each of these certifications is challenging and requires intense preparation:

tips.title: Use lab time
tips.description: All courses come with extensive lab environments. Use every minute – practice makes the difference.

tips.title: Documentation from the start
tips.description: Get used to documenting every step. This saves you valuable time during the exam.

tips.title: Use the community
tips.description: The OffSec Discord and Reddit (r/oscp, r/AskNetsec) are valuable resources for questions and motivation.

tips.title: Plan breaks
tips.description: For 48-hour exams, break management is crucial. Test your rhythm in the lab.

tips.title: Build prerequisite knowledge
tips.description: For OSWE: Solidify your programming skills. For OSED: Learn assembly basics beforehand.

commonAttackVectors.title: Common Challenges in OffSec Exams
items: Active Directory Exploitation – Kerberoasting, Pass-the-Hash, DCSync Attacks
Web Application Exploitation – SQLi, XSS, Authentication Bypasses, Deserialization
Buffer Overflow Development – Stack-based exploits with DEP/ASLR Bypasses
Privilege Escalation – Linux and Windows Post-Exploitation techniques
Network Pivoting – Lateral Movement through segmented networks
Custom Payload Development – Bypassing AV/EDR with C#, PowerShell and Shellcode

impactAnalysis.title: Career Impact: Why These Certifications Matter
impactAnalysis.content: Offensive Security certifications are among the most respected in the cybersecurity industry. They prove not just theoretical knowledge, but practical skills in realistic attack scenarios.

multipleBreaches.label: First-attempt success rate after complete lab completion

mitigationStrategies.title: Success Strategies for OffSec Certifications
mitigationStrategies.content: The key to success lies not only in technical knowledge, but also in the right approach and preparation.

essentialPractices.title: Proven Best Practices
items: Try Harder Mindset – Persistence is often more important than talent
Enumerate, Enumerate, Enumerate – Thorough information gathering is the foundation of every successful attack
Document every step – Screenshots and notes from the very first moment
Use the lab intensively – Plan at least 60-90 days of active lab time
Leverage community resources – Study groups, Discord, Reddit and OffSec Forums
Break management – For 48h exams: plan 6-8 hours of sleep
Backup strategies – Always have Plan B and C for stuck situations
Build exploit database – Maintain your own exploit library and cheat sheets

conclusion.title: Conclusion: Your Path After OSCP
conclusion.content1: OSCP is just the beginning of your Offensive Security journey. Each of the presented certifications offers unique skills and career opportunities. OSEP deepens your Red Team skills, OSWE makes you a Web Security expert, and OSED opens the door to Exploit Development.
conclusion.content2: Important: Choose the certification that matches your interests and serves your career goals. Quality over quantity – better to master one certification properly than superficially go through several.
conclusion.finalThought: And remember: These certifications are hard, but that's exactly what makes them valuable. The Offensive Security labs and exams force you to truly understand, not just memorize. That's why OffSec certifications are so highly regarded in the industry.

hero.title: About Sodu Secure
hero.description: Professional penetration testing and security services for enterprises that demand excellence. We combine technical expertise with business understanding to protect what matters most.

whoWeAre.title: Who We Are
paragraphs: Sodu Secure is growing as a focused team of seasoned offensive security specialists. We operate with startup energy and senior-level precision, lean, fast, and collaborative.

We support clients across finance, healthcare, SaaS, e-commerce, and the public sector. Our founders bring over a decade of hands-on experience, pairing modern methodologies with clear, actionable outcomes.

Our edge: human-first testing over tool autopilot. Where scanners stop, we think like attackers, creative, persistent, and certified. Every assessment is run by people who simulate real threats and give prioritized guidance.
